sn10.12:1.2: Another spirit of place, Āḷavaka’s story (also at Snp 1.10) is perhaps the most beloved of all the yakkha conversions. He is provided with an extensive backstory in the Pali commentaries, and another quite different story in a Chinese Dharmapada (T 211, pp. 575–609). | Āḷavī was a town between Sāvatthī and Rājagaha.
sn10.12:9.2: Following Cone’s Dictionary of Pali, Pali gharamesin probably stands for Sanskrit gṛhamedhin, an “householder of discernment”, a man of mature years who has completed his education.
sn10.12:10.4: Readings are uncertain. Chinese parallels at SA2 325 and SA 1326 support dama or danta here rather than dhamma. DN 30:1.6.2 has both, and elsewhere we find both dhamma and dama commonly used alongside sacca.
